meta.title: The Social Symptom Checker
meta.description: A rapid assessment of how performative suffering structures your digital identity and social validation patterns.

EN.disclaimer: DISCLAIMER: This tool is for educational and promotional purposes only. It is based on the theoretical concepts of John F. Miller and is NOT a clinical diagnostic tool. If you are experiencing mental health distress, please consult a qualified professional.

questions.text: When something difficult happens to you, how quickly do you feel compelled to share it on social media?

options.text: Immediately—it feels incomplete until I post about it
Within a few hours—I need to process it publicly
After a day or two—if it still feels relevant
Rarely—only if it has broader significance
Almost never—my struggles aren't for public consumption

questions.text: The validation you receive after sharing a personal struggle online makes you feel:

options.text: Fundamentally seen and confirmed in my existence

questions.text: Consider a moment of genuine hardship that you chose NOT to share publicly. What motivated that silence?

options.text: It wouldn't generate the right kind of response I needed
I wasn't sure how to frame it for maximum impact
It felt too personal, though I considered sharing
The experience existed independently of others' recognition
The thought of sharing never occurred to me

questions.text: When you observe someone else's suffering online without engaging, you feel:

options.text: Guilty—as though I've failed them by not witnessing properly
Slightly obligated to respond, even if I have nothing to offer
Protective of my own boundaries around emotional labour

questions.text: If all social media platforms disappeared tomorrow, the prospect of experiencing hardship without an audience would feel:

options.text: Terrifying—like suffering in a void without proof it happened
Disorienting—I'd need to find new structures for processing pain
Liberating in some ways, constraining in others
Largely irrelevant to how I experience difficulty
A relief—suffering without spectators feels more authentic

results.summary: Your suffering exists largely independent of external validation structures.
results.analysis: Your responses suggest that you have not recruited the social field as the primary guarantor of your experience's reality. This does not mean you are 'healthier'—merely that your symptoms, should they exist, operate through different circuits. You may locate meaning through internal narrative structures, or perhaps you have become so disillusioned with the symbolic order that you refuse its recognitions entirely. The risk here is not performativity but a certain psychotic foreclosure where experience cannot be symbolised at all.
results.referral: To explore how meaning-making operates outside social validation, read 'Do You Read Me', particularly the chapters on The Analyst's Silence and the collapse of the symbolic function.

results.summary: You oscillate between private experience and public witnessing without full commitment to either.
results.analysis: Your relationship to social validation reveals a fundamental ambivalence—you neither fully reject nor fully embrace the mirroring function of the social media apparatus. This suggests a neurotic structure where you remain caught between the demand to exist-for-others and the desire to exist-in-yourself. You have likely retained some capacity to experience jouissance outside the validation circuit, but you have not escaped the gravitational pull of recognition entirely. This divided position may actually preserve a certain psychic flexibility that more extreme positions foreclose.
results.referral: For an exploration of this productive ambivalence, see 'Triumphant Victim', especially the sections on Identity Performance and the ways suffering can shuttle between private symptom and public strategy.

results.summary: Social recognition has become structurally integrated into how you process and metabolise difficulty.
results.analysis: Your responses indicate that the Other's gaze has been installed as a necessary condition for experience itself to achieve reality-status. This is not merely 'attention-seeking' in the vulgar sense—it represents a profound structural dependency where suffering that goes unwitnessed feels ontologically incomplete, as though it did not fully occur. You have discovered, perhaps unconsciously, that victimhood confirmed by the social field provides a stable identity position and even a peculiar satisfaction. The danger is not that you are 'fake', but that you have become trapped in a circuit where only recognised suffering registers as real, leading to an escalating need for validation that can never be satisfied because the gap between signifier and signified remains unbridgeable.
results.referral: To understand the architecture underlying this structure, engage deeply with 'Triumphant Victim', particularly Part Two on The Economy of Suffering and how identity consolidates around performative inadequacy.

meta.title: Le Vérificateur de Symptôme Social
meta.description: Une évaluation rapide de la manière dont la souffrance performative structure votre identité numérique et vos schémas de validation sociale.

FR.disclaimer: AVERTISSEMENT: Cet outil est destiné à des fins éducatives et promotionnelles uniquement. Il est basé sur les concepts théoriques de John F. Miller et n'est PAS un outil de diagnostic clinique. Si vous souffrez de détresse psychologique, veuillez consulter un professionnel qualifié.

meta.title: El Verificador de Síntoma Social
meta.description: Una evaluación rápida de cómo el sufrimiento performativo estructura tu identidad digital y patrones de validación social.

ES.disclaimer: DESCARGO DE RESPONSABILIDAD: Esta herramienta es solo para fines educativos y promocionales. Se basa en los conceptos teóricos de John F. Miller y NO es una herramienta de diagnóstico clínico. Si experimenta angustia de salud mental, consulte a un profesional calificado.

meta.title: Den Sosiale Symptomsjekken
meta.description: En rask vurdering av hvordan performativ lidelse strukturerer din digitale identitet og sosiale valideringsmønstre.

NO.disclaimer: ANSVARSFRASKRIVELSE: Dette verktøyet er kun til pedagogiske og kampanjeformål. Det er basert på de teoretiske konseptene til John F. Miller og er IKKE et klinisk diagnostisk verktøy. Hvis du opplever psykisk nød, vennligst konsulter en kvalifisert profesjonell.

meta.title: Kontroler Symptomów Społecznych
meta.description: Szybka ocena tego, jak performatywne cierpienie strukturyzuje twoją cyfrową tożsamość i wzorce walidacji społecznej.

PL.disclaimer: ZASTRZEŻENIE: To narzędzie służy wyłącznie celom edukacyjnym i promocyjnym. Opiera się na koncepcjach teoretycznych Johna F. Millera i NIE jest klinicznym narzędziem diagnostycznym. Jeśli doświadczasz cierpienia psychicznego, skonsultuj się z wykwalifikowanym specjalistą.

meta.title: Probatio Symptomatis Socialis
meta.description: Aestimatio celera quomodo afflictio performativa identitatis digitalis tuae et rationes confirmationis socialis struunt.

LA.disclaimer: MONITUM: Hoc instrumentum solum ad fines educationis et promotionis est. In conceptibus theoreticis Ioannis F. Miller fundatur et instrumentum diagnosticum clinicum NON est. Si aegritudinem mentis pateris, professionalem qualificatum consulere debes.

meta.title: فاحص الأعراض الاجتماعية
meta.description: تقييم سريع لكيفية بناء المعاناة الأدائية لهويتك الرقمية وأنماط التحقق الاجتماعي.

EGY.disclaimer: تنويه: هذه الأداة لأغراض تعليمية وترويجية فقط. تستند إلى المفاهيم النظرية لجون ف. ميلر وليست أداة تشخيص سريري. إذا كنت تعاني من ضائقة نفسية، يرجى استشارة متخصص مؤهل.

meta.title: 社交症状检查器
meta.description: 快速评估表演性痛苦如何构建您的数字身份和社会验证模式。

ZH.disclaimer: 免责声明:此工具仅用于教育和宣传目的。它基于约翰·F·米勒的理论概念,不是临床诊断工具。如果您正在经历心理健康困扰,请咨询合格的专业人士。
